occurrences.line_text: Not fit mongst men, that doe with reason mell,
There let her wonne farre from resort of men,
Stood open wyde to all men day and night;
Who sate on high, that she might all men see,
And might of all men royally be seene:
From thence pour'd down on men, by influence of grace.
The flesh of men, to Gods owne likenesse framed,
And impotent desire of men to raine,
Nor lawes of men, that common weales containe,
Great hostes of men in order martiall,
His chearefull face, and light to men restore,
And did in strength most sorts of men surpas,
A monster, which the Blatant beast men call,
A dreadfull feend of gods and men ydrad,
Into the mindes of mortall men doe well,
From view of men, and wicked worlds disdaine.
Of Court it seemes, men Courtesie doe call,
To be the plague and scourge of wretched men:
Murdred my men, and slaine my Seneschall;
And in the eyes of men great liking find;
For knights and all men this by nature haue,
Hastily starting vp, like men dismayde,
That mote to all men seeme an vncouth sight;
And in the mindes of men had great insight;
Hast slaine my men in this vnmanly maner,
That all men did her person much admire,
That he might see his men, and muster them by oth.
As if he with his lookes would all men terrifie.
And th'hearts of men, as your eternall dowre,
Least if men you of cruelty accuse,
And from you turne the loue of men to hate.
Nor heauens, nor men can me most wretched mayd
But on the labours of poore men to feed,
To eate the flesh of men, whom they mote fynde,
In vaine (said then old Meliboe) doe men
For not that, which men couet most, is best,
Nor that thing worst, which men do most refuse;
Those three to men all gifts of grace do graunt,
These three on men all gracious gifts bestow,
To firends, to foes, which skill men call Ciuility.
Therefore the winged God, to let men weet,
What mister men, and eke from whence they were.
But most of them were tongues of mortall men,
Or fault of men, he broke his yron chaine,
To mortall men, then he had done before;
Vnto a straunge mischaunce, that menac'd her decay.
Against him bent, and fiercely did menace:
With whose reproch and odious menace
That menaced me from the field to beat,
A goodly person, and could menage faire
To menage steeds, as did this vaunter; but in vaine.
Who well could menage and subdew his pride,
And wondrous wit to menage high affaires,
Taught to obay the menage of that Elfe,
That euer warlike weapons menaged,
That in his hand a white rod menaged,
Or blamefull blot, but menaged so well,
In faire defence and goodly menaging
To sing his mistresse prayse, and let him mend,
His speares default to mend with cruell blade;
Faynd to alight, something amisse to mend;
Approching nigh, she gins to mend her pace,
Which on her waited, things amisse to mend,
Which grieu'd her more, that she it could not mend:
Sith otherwise he could not mend thing past;
All wrongs haue mends, but no amends of shame.
Such be the meede of all, that by such mene
With salue, or antidote, or other mene
In the last field before Meneuia
Euarna, and Menippe true in trust,
So liuely, and so like in all mens sight,
To haue before bewitched all mens sight;
In secret shadow, farre from all mens sight:
And poore mens boxes of their due reliefe,
Her glorious glitterand light doth all mens eyes amaze.
On th'other side in all mens open vew
First made by him, mens wandring wayes to guyde,
That rules mens wayes, and rules the thoughts of liuing wight.
And three mens strength vnto the stroke he layd;
To see sad pageants of mens miseries,
Like Angels life was then mens happy cace;
And dead mens bones, which round about were flong,
That they encombred all mens eares and eyes,
And all mens harts in dew obedience held:
So th'other did mens rash desires apall,
From all mens vew, that none might her discoure,
Yet ought mens good endeuours them confirme,
And doth for wretched mens reliefe make way;
In a fresh fountaine, farre from all mens vew,
But in close bowre her mewes from all mens sight,
That fed on liuing flesh, & druncke mens vitall blood.
Their purpost flight, free from all mens reclame;
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
That downe he fell as dead in all mens sight:
And all mens eyes and hearts, which there among
His wondrous worth declared in all mens view.
For Cambell victour was in all mens sight,
That Florimell her selfe in all mens vew
That out of all mens knowledge he was worne at last.
Flew first abroad, and all mens eares possest,
I boldly thought (so young mens thoughts are bold)
Of womens powre, that boast of mens subiection?
To mens subiection, did true Iustice deale:
He caused them be hung in all mens sight,
That deadly daunger seem'd in all mens sight,
That all she sought, was mens good name to haue bereaued.
And gracious speach, did steale mens hearts away.
The which in all mens liking gayned place,
To guide mens labours, brought them also ease,
That mucky masse, the cause of mens decay,
Where that false couple were full closely ment
In which he askt her, what the Lyon ment:
The ill, which earst to him, he now to Guyon ment.
And shund the marke, at which it should be ment,
Both what she was, and what that vsage ment,
Askt who he was, and what he ment thereby:
Ne euill thing she fear'd, ne euill thing she ment.
Yet wist not what their wailing ment, yet did
That fearefull Ladie fled from him, that ment
But what so were therein or writ or ment,
With th'other he his friends ment to enwrap:
From her, to whom his fury first he ment,
As if that each ment other to deuoure;
Full many strokes, that mortally were ment,
Where it was ment, (so deadly it was ment)
Where it was ment, (so deadly it was ment)
To weeten what that sudden clamour ment;
As if he naught but peace and pleasure ment,
What mister wight he was, or what he ment:
Her words were not, as common words are ment,
False crimes and facts, such as they neuer ment,
To whom his faith he firmely ment to hold,
He ment to make them know their follies prise,
Which being ment of mortall creatures sead,
She ment him to corrupt with goodly meede;
He ment the thiefe there deadly to haue smit:
To weeten what that trumpets sounding ment:
But bath'd in bloud and sweat together ment;
In her owne mouth the food, ment for her chyld,
As by his modest semblant, that no euill ment.
He should his purpose misse, which close he ment:
Perceiuing well the treason, which was ment:
Was ment to her, that neuer euill ment in hart.
Was ment to her, that neuer euill ment in hart.
And therefore ment him surely to haue slaine.
Towards my Ladies presence by you ment,
Eftsoones brought forth the villaine, as they ment,
To doe most dammage, where as most they ment.
And turne to ill the thing, that well was ment.
To fight with many foes about him ment,
In carelesse couch, not weeting what was ment,
To cloke the mischiefe, which he inly ment,
But scornd them all, that loue vnto her ment:
But askt againe, what ment that rufull hew;
When Scudamour heard mention of that speare,
To future age of her this mention may be made.
She much was cheard to heare him mentiond,
Which to late age were neuer mentioned.
As it in antique bookes is mentioned.
Laden from far with precious merchandize,
Whose mariners and merchants with much toyle,
To merchants, which them kept in bondage hard,
It chaunst a sort of merchants, which were wount
Now at thy mercy: Mercie not withstand:
Her name was Mercie, well knowne ouer all,
Where seeing Mercie, that his steps vp bare,
And cryde, Mercie Sir knight, and mercie Lord,
And cryde, Mercie Sir knight, and mercie Lord,
For misery craues rather mercie, then repriefe.
Saying, but if she Mercie would him giue
And to her mercie him submitted in plaine field.
And more my gratious mercie by this wize,
To weeten Mercie, be of Iustice part,
Cryde out, Ah mercie Sir, doe me not slay,
Who will not mercie vnto others shew,
Yet since ye mercie now doe need to craue,
Cryde out aloud for mercie him to saue;
But holding vp his hands, with silence mercie prayd.
Cryde mercie, to abate the extremitie of law.
In heauenly mercies hast thou not a part?
Far reach her mercies, and her prayses farre,
And euen to her foes her mercies multiply.
Royall examples of her mercies rare,
Whilest she did weepe, of no man mercifide.
Because to man so mercifull he was,
Condemned to that Dongeon mercilesse,
The Geaunt strooke so maynly mercilesse,
The monster mercilesse him made to fall,
Whose death t'auenge, his mother mercilesse,
Most mercilesse of women, VVyden hight,
To shew the victors might and mercilesse intent.
When as he saw the mercilesse affray
And all dismayd through mercilesse despaire,
In which so long he mercilesse did lie.
But they like tyrants, mercilesse the more,
And more increast her outrage mercilesse,
Her name Mercilla most men vse to call;
Which she against the dred Mercilla oft did frame.
Mercilla of her crowne, by her aspyred,
Vnto Mercilla myld for Iustice gainst the thrall.
Who then can thee, Mercilla, throughly prayse,
But vnto gratious great Mercilla call
Who hauing left Mercilla, streight way went
They to Mercillaes pallace come,
Those did vpon Mercillaes throne attend:
Caduceus the rod of Mercury,
The same she tempred with fine Mercury,
Cride, Mercy mercy Sir vouchsafe to show
Cride, Mercy mercy Sir vouchsafe to show
Now at thy mercy: Mercie not withstand:
That Mercy in the end his righteous soule might saue.
And in her face faire peace, and mercy doth appeare.
Throughout the world her mercy to maintaine,
And crying Mercy lowd, his pitious hands gan reare.
My wrathfull will, and do for mercy call.
With that he cryde, Mercy, do me not dye,
But sith in might thou didst my mercy proue,
Great mercy sure, for to enlarge a thrall,
And all his workes with mercy doth embrace,
Will not long misery late mercy make,
Mercy deare Lord (said he) what grace is this,
With which her soueraigne mercy thou doest quight?
But he her prayd, for mercy, or for meed,
But thine owne people do thy mercy prayse much more.
How can he mercy euer hope to haue?
All gan to iest and gibe full merilie
And passe the bonds of modest merimake,
In hast forsooke their rurall meriment,
So she beheld those maydens meriment
Their wanton follies, and light meriment;
That might to her moue cause of meriment:
Some to make loue, some to make meriment,
Their goodly meriment, and gay felicitie.
Of Minstrals, making goodly meriment,
So fayre a spoyle, to make you ioyous meriment?
Their wanton meriments they did encreace,
And steale from thee the meede of thy due merit,
In stupid sorow, sith thy iuster merit
With equall eyes, their merites to restore,
But he should die, who merites not to liue?
That she may thee aduance for workes and merites iust.
And meriteth to haue as high a place,
But meriteth indeede an higher name:
Though nor in word nor deede ill meriting,
All vertue merits praise, but such the most of all
That all the antique Worthies merits far did passe.
For their high merits and great dignitie,
It Merlin was, which whylome did excell
Thither the great Magicien Merlin came,
Which Merlin made by his almightie art
The great Magitian Merlin had deuiz'd,
Such was the glassie globe that Merlin made,
Merlin bewrayes to Britomart,
To weet, the learned Merlin, well could tell,
There the wise Merlin whylome wont (they say)
Before that Merlin dyde, he did intend,
For Merlin had in Magicke more insight,
But vauntage made of that, which Merlin had ared.
Then Merlin thus; Indeed the fates are firme,
But yet the end is not. There Merlin stayd,
They came, as Merlin them directed late:
Through hope of those, which Merlin had her told
Where many Mermayds haunt, making false melodies.
Where as those Mermayds dwelt: it was a still
Were met, to make their sports and merrie glee,
His chearefull whistle merrily doth sound,
At which they all gan laugh full merrily:
Full merrily, and making gladfull glee,
That made him pipe so merrily, as neuer none.
Making great feast and ioyous merriment,
And all the way their merry pipes they sound,
If Bacchus merry fruit they did inuent,
With merry note her loud salutes the mounting larke.
Till merry wind and weather call her thence away.
The merry marriner vnto his word
And greatly ioyed merry tales to faine,
Her merry fit she freshly gan to reare,
The whiles the other Ladies mind their merry glee.
Whom ouertaking, she in merry sort
Tho vp they gan their merry pypes to trusse,
First doe the merry birds, thy prety pages
Ne ought on earth that merry is and glad,
To make them both as merry as he may.
Somewhile with merry purpose fit to please,
Approcht, him seemed that the merry sound
Which piped there vnto that merry rout:
Here leadest in this goodly merry make,
Next faire Aglaia, last Thalia merry:
So forth they rode, he feining seemely merth,
That their exceeding merth may not be told:
As discontent for want of merth or meat;
Guyon is of immodest Merth,
Matter of merth enough, though there were none
New merth, her passenger to entertaine:
Her honest merth and pleasaunce to partake;
And gamesom merth to grieuous dreriment:
Her sire Typhoeus was, who mad through merth,
Who had to wife Dame Mertia the fayre,
Those yet of her be Mertia[n] lawes both nam'd & thought.
The warlike Mertians for feare to quake:
But more she meruaild that no footings trace,
Against the course of kind, ne meruaile nought,
But most they meruail[e]d at her cheualree,
That Guyon meruayld at her vncouth cace:
And merueild at his strange intendiment;
Much merueiled thereat, as well he might,
His mery oaten pipe, but shund th'vnlucky ground.
Saint George of mery England, the signe of victoree.
Therein the mery birds of euery sort
But beare the rigour of his bold mesprise,
And eke reward the wretch for his mesprise,
T'asswage his wrath, and pardon their mesprise.
Which through great disauenture, or mesprize,
With loue of her, and shame of such mesprize.
The one of them he gaue a message too,
Goe guiltie ghost, to him my message make,
Thy selfe thy message doe to german deare,
Abide, till I haue told the message, which I haue.
A Messenger with letters, which his message said.
(Said Guyon,) let that message to thy Lord be brought.
But Britomart would not such guilfull message know.
To doe the message, which I shall expresse.
Till they had told their message word by word:
To beare vnto her loue the message of her mind.
So me in message vnto her she sent,
Which message when Grantorto heard, full fayne
The Dwarfe, which bore that message to her knight,
Declar'd the message, which that Knight did moue;
His mindes sad message backe vnto him sent;
And sent close messages of loue to her at will.
As messenger of Morpheus on them cast
The messenger approching to him spake,
The messenger of death, the ghastly Owle
The messenger of so vnhappie newes
As it a running messenger had beene.
A Messenger with letters, which his message said.
This craftie messenger with letters vaine,
Bad on that Messenger rude hands to reach.
As that faire Starre, the messenger of morne,
The ill-faste Owle, deaths dreadfull messengere,
To wreake her on that mayden messengere,
When those accursed messengers of hell,
The hatefull messengers of heauy things,
As messengers of his true meaning and intent.
To messengers, that come for causes iust:
A knight her met in mighty armes embost,
As when two Bores with rancling malice met,
He wofull Ladie, wofull Vna met,
We met that villen (God from him me blesse)
Him at the threshold met, and well did enterprize.
As when a Beare and Tygre being met
Hath now fast bound, me met in middle space,
And in the way he with Sir Guyon met,
Cymochles, that had neuer met before
And eke the fairest Alma met him there
That of a single damzell thou wert met
By sea, by land, where so they may be met,
He met a Dwarfe, that seemed terrifyde
Their steel-hed speares they strongly coucht, and met
And of eachone he met, he tydings did inquere.
Long wandred they, yet neuer met with none,
So furiously they met, that either bare
A trompet blew; they both together met,
With that they both together fiercely met,
Against so many no lesse mightie met,
So furiously they both together met,
Met him mid-way with equall hardiment,
With which he all that met him, downe did beare.
Met here together; where through lewd vpbraide
As when a Dolphin and a Sele are met,
What thing so many nations met, did there desire.
Together met, of all to make an end.
With Braggadochio, whom he lately met
Streight way so soone as both together met,
Both which to barre, he with this answere met her;
That if two met, the one mote needes fall ouer the lidge.
Are met at spoyling of some hungry pray,
Like fiercely met. But Artegall was stronger,
Together met, and strongly either strooke
He met him with a counterstroke so swift,
There as he traueld by the way, he met
But ere he marched farre, he with them met,
When as two old ill fauour'd Hags he met,
Whenas by chaunce he met vppon a day
So passed we, till this young man vs met,
Doth noble courage shew, with curteous manners met.
They met together in that luckelesse glade;
Prince Arthur and young Timias, which met
Met him in chase, but he it challenge would,
So both together traueld, till they met
At last he met two knights to him vnknowne,
Met her in such misseeming foule array;
They met Prince Arthure with Sir Enias,
The villaine met him in the middle fall,
With other diuelish ceremonies met:
Were met, to make their sports and merrie glee,
T'inquire for slaues; where being readie met
Is met of many a counter winde and tyde,
But most were stampt, and in their metall bare
And with rich metall loaded euery rift,
To melt the golden metall, ready to be tride.
Some scumd the drosse, that from the metall came;
The metall first he mixt with MedÃ¦wart,
That the rich metall lurked priuily,
In the rich metall, as they liuing were:
Some baser metall, which commend he will
To hide the metall, which yet euery where
For of most perfect metall it was made,
With precious mettall full, as they might hold,
Ne molten mettall in his bloud embrew:
For the rich mettall was so coloured,
But glauncing on the tempred mettall, brast
The stubborne mettall seeketh to subdew,
So pure the mettall was, and well refynd,
Of the bright mettall, shyning like Sunne rayes;
Such earthly mettals soone consumed bene:
She findes forth comming from her darkesome mew,
But safe I haue them kept in secret mew,
Had she not fled into a secret mew,
Ran with her fast away vnto his mew,
In which vaine Braggadocchio was mewed,
And after her the Hag, there with her mewed,
Captiu'd eternally in yron mewes,
But in close bowre her mewes from all mens sight,
When she with Mars was meynt in ioyfulnesse:
With an embrodered belt of mickell pride;
And mickle worship in his natiue land;
And sure he was a man of mickle might,
Constantius, a man of mickle might,
A mightie man at armes, and mickle fame
He on the bancke arriu'd with mickle paine,
Which they had past with mickle ieopardy,
And mickle perill to be put to shame.
And was indeed a man of mickle might:
Yet litle losse it were, and mickle thanke,
In which they measur'd mickle weary way,
But seeming to haue suffred mickle wrong,
Yet warded well by one of mickle might,
And mickle mischiefe vnto many a knight,
Cald Maleffort, a man of mickle might,
That in his youth had beene of mickle might,
Is hight Sir Turpine, one of mickle might,
That he had bene a man of mickle name,
The direfull distaffe standing in the mid,
Ne suffred she the Middayes scorching powre,
Yet the stout Faerie mongst the middest crowd
Sat downe to rest in middest of the race:
In middest of their mournfull Tragedy,
And both against the middest meant to worken woe.
Right in the middest of that Paradise,
The beast astonisht stands in middest of his smart.
At Artegall, in middest of his pryde,
Was in the middest plast among them all;
But right sate in the middest of the beame alone.
Right in the middest of the threshold lay,
They bene ymett in middest of the plaine,
Him ouertooke in middest of his race:
And in the middest of those same three, was placed
And cruell combat ioynd in middle space:
Hath now fast bound, me met in middle space,
Might not the same about her middle weare.
The God of warre, she from her middle loosd,
Which being brought, about her middle small
And hauing it about her middle set,
The earth was in the middle centre pight,
But in the middle way they were ymet
From rudely pressing to the middle center;
That with her wreathed taile her middle did enfold.
They both encounter in the middle plaine,
And meeting him right in the middle race,
The villaine met him in the middle fall,
About their middles that faire belt to knit;
And in the midst thereof one pretious stone
Through midst thereof a little riuer rold,
A flaming fire in midst of bloudy field,
That floted in the midst of that great lake:
And in the midst thereof a siluer seat,
The smoke forth threw. And in the midst of all
And in the midst thereof vpon the floure,
Suddeine they see from midst of all the Maine,
And in the midst of all, a fountaine stood,
And in the midst a little riuer plaide
Proceeding to the midst, he still did stand,
Therewith a sunder in the midst it brast,
First in the midst to set that fayrest Dame,
Midst sorrow shewing ioyous semblance for his sake.
And in the midst thereof a piller placed;
Right in the midst the Goddesse selfe did stand
And in the midst of them a goodly mayd,
And in the midst thereof did horror dwell,
Right in the midst, whereas they brest to brest
And in the midst of them he saw a Knight,
Thorough the midst of them she way did make.
And in the midst of her felicity,
Rebutting him, which in the midst did ryde,
And new life to her lent, in midst of deadly feare.
And in the midst a Shepheard piping he did see.
And daunced round ; but in the midst of them
But she that in the midst of them did stand,
That in the midst was placed parauaunt,
